entry.et: Middle English, from Middle Low German; akin to Old High German trata track, course, Old English tredan to tread

def.dt: :a path traversed :way
:a track or trail left by a person or animal :tread 1
:a customary course of action :practice thy sin's not accidental, but a trade Shakespeare
:the business or work in which one engages regularly :occupation
:an occupation requiring manual or mechanical skill :craft
:the persons engaged in an occupation, business, or industry
:dealings between persons or groups
:the business of buying and selling or bartering commodities :commerce
:business market novelties for the tourist trade did a good trade in small appliances
:an act or instance of trading :transaction
:an exchange of property usually without use of money
:a firm's customers :clientele
:the group of firms engaged in a business or industry
:trade wind usually used in plural
:a publication intended for persons in the entertainment business usually used in plural
:to have dealings :negotiate
:to engage in the exchange, purchase, or sale of goods
:to make one's purchases :shop trades at his store
:to give one thing in exchange for another
:sell 3
:to do business with
:to give in exchange for another commodity :barter
:to make an exchange of traded places
:to engage in frequent buying and selling of (as stocks or commodities) usually in search of quick profits
:to take often unscrupulous advantage of :exploit traded on their influence … in securing special favors T. C. Pease
:of, relating to, or used in trade
:intended for or limited to persons in a business or industry a trade publication trade sales
:serving others in the same business rather than the ultimate user or consumer a trade printing house
:of, composed of, or representing the trades or trade unions a trade committee
:having a larger softcover format than that of a mass-market paperback and usually sold only in bookstores trade paperbacks
:of or relating to the publishing of such books
:a time draft or bill of exchange for the amount of a specific purchase drawn by the seller on the buyer, bearing the buyer's acceptance, and often noting the place of payment (as a bank)
:an international agreement on conditions of trade in goods and services
:an agreement resulting from collective bargaining
:a book intended for general readership
:trade edition
:a deduction from the list price of goods allowed by a manufacturer or wholesaler to a retailer
:a United States silver dollar weighing 420 grains .900 fine issued 1873–85 for use in east Asian trade
:to trade something in (as an automobile) for something less expensive or valuable of its kind
:to stock or purchase lower-priced items :economize
:an edition of a book intended for general distribution compare text edition
